messages: 3b630800966be5c4f7eb283c363eb7f4 (23:12): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: hi anne
3b630800966be5c4f7eb283c363eb7f4 (23:15): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: how are you doing?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (23:16): pretty good, bit sleepy :)
3b630800966be5c4f7eb283c363eb7f4 (23:16): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: I see. I'm a bit confused about the whole discussion on HTMLCollection
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (23:16): still trying to get used to the cold after my shortish break
3b630800966be5c4f7eb283c363eb7f4 (23:17): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: oh oops, that sucks.
3b630800966be5c4f7eb283c363eb7f4 (23:17): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: hopefully it gets better.
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (23:17): well I think sicking wants to add new members to e.g. NodeList at some point
3b630800966be5c4f7eb283c363eb7f4 (23:17): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: yeah, that makes sense.
3b630800966be5c4f7eb283c363eb7f4 (23:17): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: but do you think he's opposed to make getElement*by* return HTMLCollection?

edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (23:18): HTMLCollection has a named getter which would make that difficult if e.g. someone used an ID anywhere on the web and that matches the new member name while also using HTMLCollection in some way
3b630800966be5c4f7eb283c363eb7f4 (23:18): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: as I noted on the thread, I filed a WebKit bug and was intending to work on it this weekend or so
3b630800966be5c4f7eb283c363eb7f4 (23:18): but it sounded as if jonas doesn't want that.
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (23:19): I think he was somewhat opposed to getElementsByClassName, not the others
3b630800966be5c4f7eb283c363eb7f4 (23:20): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: FWIW, we're never got complaints about named getters so maybe we can disable that feature?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (23:21): I think even WebKit has a named getter for getElementsByTagName
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (23:21): bz pointed that out
3b630800966be5c4f7eb283c363eb7f4 (23:21): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: ah, you're right.
3b630800966be5c4f7eb283c363eb7f4 (23:21): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: we had that extension on NodeList :(
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (23:21): yeah so this change would mean you can try to clean that up
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (23:22): gonna go watch some parks and recreation
3b630800966be5c4f7eb283c363eb7f4 (23:22): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: I will definitely do that assuming there's no compat. issues
3b630800966be5c4f7eb283c363eb7f4 (23:23): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: alright. ttyl.
3b630800966be5c4f7eb283c363eb7f4 (23:24): is so confused by Objective-C syntax
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (23:33): hmm, would be nice to get HTML's use of "default action" updated to use DOM4 terms (canceled flag) ... low editorial priority, i assume
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (23:34): 3b630800966be5c4f7eb283c363eb7f4: objc is one of the few languages that simply doesn't make even the most basic intuitive sense to me
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (23:34): putting aside weirdo functional languages, I guess

3b630800966be5c4f7eb283c363eb7f4 (23:36): 06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6: I mean it's a declarative language. but I find declarative programming languages even less intuitive than functional programming languages.

06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (23:37): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: is the preferred way to look at "canceled flag" after dispatch to refer to the flag directly, or to use the return value of the "dispatch" algo
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (23:37): the latter seems more natural to me (but then there'd be no reason to have the return value at all, I think)
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (23:38): the former looks more natural (using the flag directly)
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (23:44): 06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6: you'd use fire so there's no return value I think
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (23:46): could maybe move the return value to dispatchEvent()
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (23:46): "fire" only lets you create a basic Event, for events with other interfaces, etc. you want dispatch directly, right?
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (23:46): that's what i was thinking
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (23:46): no fire is also used for events with other interfaces
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (23:46): you'd use a modified fire definition
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (23:46): how? sounds contradictory
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (23:47): http://dev.w3.org/2006/webapi/progress/#firing-events-using-the-progressevent-interface-for-http
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (23:47): because otherwise you also need to set the trusted flag, etc.
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (23:47): yeah that looks contradictory
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (23:47): it's saying "dispatch an event using the Event interface using the ProgressEvent interface" :)
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (23:48): not that it's not obvious what's really meant
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (23:48): not if you read it in the way that it's overriding
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (23:48): which is more logical imo
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (23:51): replying to clipboard thread suggesting:

06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (23:51): 7. Fire an event using the ClipboardEvent interface, with its type attribute initialized to e and its clipboardData attribute initialized to data transfer, at event target. If the event's canceled flag is set then abort these steps.
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (23:55): the if statement should prolly be step 8 for clarity

06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (23:55): it was before, i moved it into 7 based on http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/association-of-controls-and-forms.html#form-submission-algorithm step 6
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (23:56): hmm
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (23:56): seems like having a concise pattern for this is good ... not sure if it's unclear or not
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (23:57): maybe I should postpone encoding stuff a bit more and work on DOM next week too
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (23:59): let me know if you think strongly one way or the other; don't want to bait people like paul by going back and forth
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:00): I don't, it's something that can be mended easily over time
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:01): especially if we make specs more hackable
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (00:01): ("this spec hasn't been set in stone so it can start getting out of date, so everyone should use a useless, confusing, decade-old spec" sigh)
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:04): yeah i don't know what's up with that

edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:04): i can sort of see the i want-to-play-by-silly-rules-so-i-cannot-reference-what-implementors-actually-need, but if you need to reference the newer draft anyway, also referencing crappy material is just wrong
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:05): that you even need to argue such a point because of some hearsay about "hot debate"
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:05): ugh
